title: Consecutive Smooth Numbers
description: Are there infinitely many n such that both n and n+1 have their largest prime factor less than their square root? Steinerberger found an elegant solution using n = m² - 1.

overview.historicalContext: This problem from Erdős-Graham (1980) asks about consecutive integers whose largest prime factors are unusually small. Pomerance observed that relaxing the exponent from 1/2 to 1/√e - ε gives a positive density result. Steinerberger found an elegant construction: n = m² - 1 works when m is chosen appropriately.
overview.problemStatement: Are there infinitely many n such that gpf(n) < √n and gpf(n+1) < √(n+1), where gpf denotes the greatest prime factor?
overview.proofStrategy: We axiomatize gpf with key properties and formalize the Steinerberger construction n = m² - 1 = (m-1)(m+1). For n = 63 = 8² - 1, we verify gpf(63) = 7 < √63 and gpf(64) = 2 < √64. The main theorem states infinitely many such n exist.
keyInsights: The key construction is n = m² - 1 = (m-1)(m+1)
Then n + 1 = m², so gpf(n+1) = gpf(m)

conclusion.summary: We formalize Erdős Problem #370 about consecutive smooth numbers. The Steinerberger construction n = m² - 1 provides infinitely many examples where both n and n+1 have their largest prime factor less than their square root.
conclusion.implications: This connects the distribution of smooth numbers to elementary number theory. The elegant solution shows how sometimes deep-sounding problems have simple answers.
